and is well known for gaming and the great outdoors, culinary delights and rhythm and blues. There are over 75 annual festivals from the splendor of Mardi Gras to the swashbuckling days of the Contraband Days Pirate Festival, there is something going on nearly every weekend.

value: United Airlines serves the Lake Charles Regional Airport (LCH) with nonstop flights to/from Houston Bush Intercontinental Airport.
American Eagle serves LCH with nonstop flights to/from the Dallas/Ft. Worth International Airport.
serves the station located at 100 Ryan St.

Driving is the best way to get around Lake Charles, although Historic Downtown is a pedestrian friendly area and it is easy to walk to most downtown attractions.

value: content=This 375 year old live oak tree marked the corner of early resident Charles Sallier's property and is thought to be the 3rd oldest live oak in Louisiana. It stretches to create a canopy with some branches sagging all the way to the ground.

content=Built in 1962, this steep bridge has a vertical clearance of 135 feet. Drive slow enough to check out the decorative cast-iron pistols that embellish the railing over the entire length of the bridge. Traveling west-bound you will top the crest of the bridge to view a vast landscape of plants and oil refineries. This can be an oddly spectacular sight, especially at twilight.
directions=just east of the I-10 bridge, south of the highway

content=On the north shore of Lake Charles is the only naturally occurring inland white sand beach on the Gulf Coast. It is also very close to Interstate 10, true. Nevertheless, there are volleyball nets, picnic tables, restrooms, and a full view of the Lake. The waters are not the cleanest as there are refineries in the area, but it is ok if you;re not looking for superclear water.
directions=Off of I-10 at the downtown exit

content=The CVB is an attractive new building that looks out over the Lake and provides visitors with info, maps, calendars, and brochures covering the Southwest region of Louisiana. There is a deck to relax with some free coffee, a gift shop with unique Louisiana finds, and even an alligator pond! They will tell you about driving tours of the area and events that are going on.
directions=Along the northern & eastern shores of the Lake

content=Visit Veterans Memorial park , Bord Du Lac Park, and a fountain that is ok to play in. There are plaques detailing Lake Charles history, geese to feed, and plenty of places to sit and catch the lakeside breeze, including gazebos built onto docks over the Lake.The newly rebuilt Millenium Park is an excellent, very large playground for kids of all ages. Fenced in, whimsical, best playground in town. There are also horse carriage rides. All in all, this is a great area of town for anyone to stop and take a break from a long car ride. Right off I-10.
content=Play gyms, swings, a walking trail, picnic tables and oak trees. A community center with indoor activities like pool and video games.
content=Walking paths, canoe and boat launches, playground and sprayground, amphitheater, pavilions and free WiFi.
directions=off of Hwy 378 in Moss Bluff

content=Swampy lakes, cypress trees, hiking trails, 200 species of birds, and camping. If you like the quintessential southern image of lots of Spanish moss everywhere, this is it. There is a playground and swings amid great scenery. Lots of picnic spots by the river. The trails are great for bicyclers.

content=The Museum houses an historical collection of artifacts from the five surrounding parishes, as well as a gallery featuring arts and cultural exhibits. Behind the Museum stands the 375 year old Sallier Oak- this is a great place for a picnic in the shade.
directions=looping towards the Gulf, south of Lake Charles

content=This scenic drive takes you south from Lake Charles, along the Gulf of Mexico, and north again to Sulphur, LA which is just west of Lake Charles. There are plenty of coastal swamplands to see, very natural beaches, and wetlands wildlife. The wildlife refuge has a trail where alligators can be spotted, as well as many docks to go crabbing (which does not require a fishing license). An audio tour is available for download on the website. A detailed map of the route can be found either on the website, or at the Convention and Visitors Bureau.
content=Racetrack casino with hotel, dining, gaming and entertainment.
content=Two casinos, two hotels, four restaurants, live music and entertainment.
content=Resort hotel, golf club, 8 restaurants, spa, pool with lazy river, live entertainment, coffee shop, gelato shop, and shopping.
content= Three floors of hands-on, educational exhibits in a family atmosphere. Features many exhibits including television studio, shopping market, toddler area, and several science exhibits.
name=Mardi Gras Museum of Imperial Calcasieu
content=Largest Mardi Gras costume display in the world, history of Mardi Gras and king cakes, costume design, parade float to climb aboard.

content=Restored building which hosts three floors of gallery space for traveling exhibitions. Permanent exhibition of the Great Fire of 1910 which destroyed the building before it was rebuilt in 1911.

content=Boudin is considered a staple snack of the Bayou State, seasoned meat and rice formed into a fingerfood, it's perfect for breakfast, lunch or dinner! Pick up a copy of the Boudin Trail brochure at the Visitor's Bureau and travel around Calcasieu Parish trying all varieties of Boudin.
content=Exotic imported furniture, accessories and gifts from all over the world.
content=Fragrances, jewelry, shoes, purses, fleur de lis items, and home decor.
content=Children's heirloom clothing, toys and gifts.
content=Full service pharmacy and unique gifts.
content=Regional Simon shopping center. Dillard's, Sears, JCPenny's, Kohls.
content=Brighton jewelry, Sweet Shop chocolates, boutique, home decor, bath and body.
content=Great selection of boutique wines. Specializing in small production, hand crafted wines.  Gourmet cheeses. Custom gift baskets. Wine tastings every Th 5PM-7PM.
content=Small farmer's market with fruits/vegetables, specialty jams, candles, artisan breads, etc. 8AM-12PM every Saturday.

content=Slightly more upscale Cajun food in a relaxed atmosphere. Good luncheon specials. Shamelessly rich- they actually give you the butter that your fish was fried in so that you can dip in it! The crawfish fettuccine is a favorite.
content=transports you to Mexico with their decor and staff. The food is full of flavor that everyone will enjoy.

content=a Lake Charles staple. Serving the lake area since 1968, Tony's is a favorite by many. Family owned and operated by the Dickson family of Lake Charles, it is a great place to bring the family. With an entire menu of delicious food from Italian Pizza, Po-Boys, Pasta, and Salads,to Greek Gyros, it will be impossible to make a bad decision.

content=If you're looking for mouth watering steaks go no further than the family run Harlequin Steaks & Seafood. The friendly staff will ensure that you have an enjoyable meal. The Harlequin is great for business trips, with private party rooms and being conveniently located near the interstate, or romatic dinners with a significant other.
content=Fine dining with French, southwest, Louisiana and Mediterranean influences.
content=Stone hearth cooking, pizza, seafood, steak and sandwiches. One of the best evening dining atmospheres in LC, and amazing calzones.

content=For the same price as any other Chinese buffet, or for the same price as a roll of sushi, you can have both! The sushi is very good for all-you-can-eat, and there is a lot of seafood on the buffet. You will definitely get your money's worth.
hours=M-F 10-4:30PM and 1st & 3rd Sat of the month 9-1PM
content=Tea house and cafe, tea parties, lunch.
content=American, Cajun, and French bistro with a historic downtown feel. Porch seating.
content=Hole in the wall delicious, mufflettas, poboys, gumbo and fried anything.
content=Cajun/Creole, boiled seafood in a family friendly atmosphere.
content=Lake Charles' oldest restaurant, est. 1950. Diner-style, home-cooked breakfast and lunch.

content=Cajun (AKA fried) seafood, featured in USA Today. You can eat this type of food anywhere in Lake Charles, but Steamboat Bill's appeals to tourists, with a fun atmosphere and convenient location just off of I-10.

content=This bar has a hip atmosphere with it's exposed brick used to display local artist's work. It has a long, shaded patio with live music on many nights. The drink prices are reasonable, and the food is great, too. Their spinach and artichoke dip is out of this world.
content=Big screen TV for sports, live Cajun music and dancing every Friday night.
content=Bar with live music, DJs and dancing.
content=Frozen drinks and beer, Karaoke Thurs-Sat, pool, shuffleboard.
content=Features live entertainment every Thurs-Sat night.
content=Retail cigar store and elegant lounge with full bar.
content=Bar and Grill with music, dancing etc.
content=Deli with connected pub. 30 beers on tap.

content=Locally owned and operated coffee house with a hip, relaxing atmosphere with Louisiana's favorite "Community Coffee", as well as "Higher Grounds" a fair-trade coffee, roasted in the South. They also have breakfast sandwiches and rich soups/salads for lunch.
content=Bar with live music, DJs, dancing.
name=L'Auberge du Lac Hotel and Casino
name=Isle of Capri Casino & Hotel Lake Charles
